parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Forest canopy opening through clearing, coppicing, and thinning has differential effects on butterfly and moth communities.
[Statement 2]: Thinning trees within forests generally increases butterfly species richness and abundance.
[Statement 3]: Coniferous woodland thinned along with prescribed burning, mulching, or nearby felling had greater species richness of butterflies compared to unmanaged woodland.
[Statement 4]: Coniferous woodland thinned along with prescribed burning, mulching, or nearby felling had a higher abundance of all butterflies or specialist butterflies compared to unmanaged woodland.
[Statement 5]: Partially-cleared forest plots had higher butterfly species richness than closed-canopy forest.
[Statement 6]: Partially-cleared forest plots had lower moth species richness than closed-canopy forest.
[Statement 7]: Clearing or opening patches in forests shows mixed effects depending on the taxa and patch characteristics.
[Statement 8]: Cleared patches had greater species richness of butterflies than unmanaged patches or closed canopy forest.
[Statement 9]: Cleared patches had lower species richness of moths than unmanaged patches or closed canopy forest.
[Statement 10]: Larger cleared patches supported higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than undisturbed forest.
[Statement 11]: Smaller cleared patches did not show a higher species richness and abundance of butterflies compared to undisturbed forest.
[Statement 12]: Cleared patches generally had a higher abundance of butterflies compared to before management or in unmanaged areas.
[Statement 13]: Cleared patches had a higher abundance of specific butterfly species like chequered blue, woodland brown, high brown fritillary, and small pearl-bordered fritillary, compared to before management or in unmanaged areas.
[Statement 14]: A review across Europe reported that clearing small patches in forests benefitted 19 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.
[Statement 15]: Coppicing woodland creates varying effects based on the age of the coppice.
[Statement 16]: Coppiced woodland had greater species richness of butterflies than unmanaged woodland.
[Statement 17]: Coppiced woodland had lower species richness of macro-moths than mature forest.
[Statement 18]: The abundance of butterflies was higher in woodland coppiced 2-4, 5-7, or 12-15 years ago than in woodland coppiced over 15 years ago.
[Statement 19]: Heath fritillary populations were more likely to persist for up to 20 years in coppiced woodland than in mature conifer woodland.
[Statement 20]: Alternative harvesting methods show different impacts compared to clearcutting.
[Statement 21]: Thinning resulted in higher macro-moth species richness than patch-cutting or clearcutting.
[Statement 22]: Macro-moth species richness in thinned forests was similar to richness in unharvested forest.
[Statement 23]: Selective logging produced similar species richness of moths to group selection harvesting or clearcutting.
[Statement 24]: Selective logging produced lower species richness of moths than unharvested forest.
[Statement 25]: Selectively logged forests had a higher abundance of exposed moth caterpillars compared to clearcut forests.
[Statement 26]: Selectively logged forests had a similar abundance of concealed moth caterpillars compared to clearcut forests.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the effects on butterfly and moth communities of opening up forest canopies through clearing, coppicing, or thinning?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Both rotational burning and leaving unburned patches during prescribed fires show benefits for butterfly populations in prairies.
[Statement 2]: The abundance of Karner blue butterflies increased over 2-3 years in oak savannas and prairies where unburned patches were left during prescribed burning.
[Statement 3]: Six out of nine specialist butterfly species were more abundant at sites with unburned areas compared to sites without unburned areas.
[Statement 4]: One specialist butterfly species was less abundant at sites with unburned areas compared to sites without unburned areas.
[Statement 5]: Two specialist butterfly species had similar abundance at sites with unburned areas compared to sites without unburned areas.
[Statement 6]: Karner blue butterflies were recorded using all 11 unburned patches surveyed within oak savannas and prairies managed by burning.
[Statement 7]: The total abundance of prairie specialist, grassland and all butterflies was higher on prairies burned more than one, two or four years ago than on prairies burned in the last one or two years under rotational burning management.
[Statement 8]: The abundance of grassland and generalist butterflies was highest in the third year after burning.
[Statement 9]: The abundance of migrant butterflies was highest in the first year after burning.
[Statement 10]: Two studies found that pine-oak barrens and prairies managed by rotational burning every 2-5 years had a higher total abundance of butterflies than unmanaged sites.
[Statement 11]: Rotational burning showed mixed effects across different studies.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found lower abundance of butterflies in rotationally burned prairies compared to unmanaged areas in certain regions.
[Statement 13]: Regal fritillary abundance was higher in grasslands managed by rotational burning every three years than on unmanaged sites.
[Statement 14]: The abundance of Regal fritillary butterflies was higher in rotationally burned prairies four years after the last burn than one or eight years after the last burn.
[Statement 15]: Some studies found that regal fritillary and arogos skipper butterflies were less abundant in burned prairies compared to hayed prairies.
[Statement 16]: Karner blue butterfly abundance was similar in rotationally burned and unmanaged oak savannas and prairies.
[Statement 17]: Both rotational burning and leaving unburned patches provide refugia and recovery opportunities for butterfly populations.
[Statement 18]: The timing since the last burn appears critical for the effectiveness of rotational burning.
[Statement 19]: Unburned patches provide immediate refugia for butterfly populations during active burning periods.

_claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to mitigate the negative impacts of artificial lighting on moth populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several specific lighting modification actions are available to mitigate negative impacts of artificial lighting on moth populations.
[Statement 2]: Using shielded "full cut-off" lights to remove outwards lighting was found to attract fewer individual moths and moth species compared to conventional lights without blinds or filters.
[Statement 3]: Using low intensity lighting reduced moth attraction compared to higher intensity lights.
[Statement 4]: Fewer moths were attracted to low intensity lights that emitted a narrower range of yellow light with little UV compared to higher intensity lights with broader spectra including UV.
[Statement 5]: Using 'warmer' red or yellow lighting rather than other lighting colors significantly reduced moth attraction.
[Statement 6]: Fewer individual moths and moth species were attracted to yellow, green, white, or red lights compared to UV, actinic, blue, or conventional metal halide lights.
[Statement 7]: One study found that four moth species spent more time feeding under red lights than under white or green lights.
[Statement 8]: One study found that four moth species spent less time feeding under red, white, or green lights than when in complete darkness.
[Statement 9]: Restricting the use of polarized light is a potentially beneficial action for butterfly and moth conservation, though this intervention has not yet been evaluated by studies.
[Statement 10]: Using glazing treatments to reduce light spill from inside lit buildings is a potentially beneficial action for butterfly and moth conservation, though this intervention has not yet been evaluated by studies.
[Statement 11]: Restricting the timing of lighting to conserve areas with natural light regimes is a potentially beneficial action for butterfly and moth conservation, though this intervention has not yet been evaluated by studies.
[Statement 12]: Minimizing road lighting to reduce insect attraction is a potentially beneficial action for butterfly and moth conservation, though this intervention has not yet been evaluated by studies.
[Statement 13]: Removing or changing turbine lighting to reduce insect attraction is a potentially beneficial action for butterfly and moth conservation, though this intervention has not yet been evaluated by studies.

[Statement 1]: The long-term success of re-establishing butterfly populations through translocation or captive-release shows mixed results.
[Statement 2]: For translocation programs within a species' former range, eight studies reported that translocated populations persisted for 2-12 years and increased in abundance.
[Statement 3]: Three studies found that while some translocated populations persisted for 1-49 years and increased in abundance, other populations died out within 0-7 years.
[Statement 4]: A review across the UK and Ireland found that only 25% of translocated and released captive-bred butterfly populations survived for at least three years.
[Statement 5]: A review across the UK and Ireland found that 38% of translocated and released captive-bred butterfly populations died out within a three-year timeframe.
[Statement 6]: A review across the UK and Ireland found that only 8% of translocated and released captive-bred butterfly populations survived for more than 10 years.
[Statement 7]: Another review reported that translocated large copper populations survived for up to 38 years but ultimately died out or required supplementation by further releases.
[Statement 8]: For translocations outside a species' known range, two of three studies reported populations persisting and increasing in abundance over 8 and 28 years.
[Statement 9]: For translocations outside a species' known range, one population died out within one year.
[Statement 10]: For captive-bred releases, six studies reported populations persisting for 2-28 years and increasing in abundance.
[Statement 11]: For captive-bred releases, two studies found populations died out after 1, 2, or 12 years or required further releases to survive.
[Statement 12]: One study found that three of ten captive-bred populations became established.
[Statement 13]: One study found that at least one established captive-bred population persisted for five years.
[Statement 14]: A review found that 25% of captive-bred populations survived for more than 3 years.
[Statement 15]: A review found that 38% of captive-bred populations died out within 3 years.
[Statement 16]: A review found that only 8% of captive-bred populations survived for more than 10 years.
[Statement 17]: Released captive-bred caterpillars showed lower survival rates than wild or translocated caterpillars.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The documented effects of excluding different types of herbivores on butterfly and moth populations show mixed but generally positive outcomes.
[Statement 2]: For vertebrate herbivore exclusion, five of eight studies found that forest and grassland plots fenced to exclude or reduce the density of deer, sheep, pigs and large herbivores had a higher abundance of butterflies, moths, caterpillars, rare macro-moths and New Forest burnet moths than unfenced plots.
[Statement 3]: Two of four replicated studies found that forest plots fenced to exclude or reduce the density of non-native pigs and deer had greater species richness of butterflies and macro-moths than unfenced plots.

[Statement 7]: A global systematic review found that reducing or removing grazing or browsing by wild or domestic herbivores in temperate and boreal forests did not affect species richness.
[Statement 8]: All Glanville fritillary caterpillar nests survived in grassland fenced to exclude sheep, compared to 88% survival in grazed areas.
[Statement 9]: Fewer Glanville fritillary caterpillar nests were damaged in fenced areas compared to grazed areas.
